title: Basics of Business Law
headline: This free online course covers the essential laws and legislative frameworks that define business law in the UK.
description: ‘Business law’ governs business commercial transactions by convention, agreement or legislation. We delve into the workings of commercial law and compare it to criminal law. This course covers European Community Law and traces its links to the UK’s court system. We examine civil court proceedings, outline contracts and lay out the benefits of employment law. This course provides crucial information required to legally conduct business in the UK.

courseDescription:
Business law, sometimes called ‘commercial’ or ‘mercantile’ law, governs financial transactions by convention, agreement or national or international law. We begin by studying the nature of law, particularly those applicable in the United Kingdom. We also outline European Community Law before examining specific regulations, directives and decisions. We establish the benefits of understanding these important pieces of legislation.

The course explores the English court system and explains how to analyse information about civil court proceedings. We simplify the complexities of agency, consumer and contract business law and provide practical ways to handle disputes. The course also examines the tort laws governing civil lawsuits and answers questions like ‘what is the three-stage test?’ and ‘how can one identify a breach of duty?’.

We cover the primary laws of the UK and explain how they apply to your business. We outline precise rules and structural foundations and provide practical explanations so you can confidently use them in your workplace. This course forms a foundation on which to build the necessary understanding of the UK’s laws, legislation, and duties surrounding business. Sign up to meet your tax and legal obligations while taking advantage of employee and contract law.

Start Course Now

All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this certificate course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this certificate course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison certificate is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital certificate: a downloadable certificate in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked certificate, posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security marked certificate in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.
Start Course Now

All certificate are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison certificate, please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison certificate, you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our certificate pricing, please visit our Pricing Page

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, we will help you analyse what business law is. We will also analyse the nature of law, including the characteristics of English law. In addition, we will examine regulations, directives, and decisions. We will help you answer questions like: What is alternative dispute resolution? What are the elements of a contract?

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, we will help you analyse what agency law is. In addition, we will examine terms implicit in contracts. The module will review the "what" and "why" of unincorporated and incorporated business organisations. We will help you answer questions like: "What is a public company?" or "What are the rights over the property of another?"

topics: Basics of Business Law - Course assessment

slides:
• Understanding Business Law - Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Analyse a complete understanding of business laws.
    • Identify the various laws related to European Community Law.
    • Discuss the statutes that regulate the court system.
    • Recognise the meaning of civil and dispute resolution.
    • Explain each component that makes up contract business law.
    • Summarise what employment law is.

  • Understanding Business Law - Lesson Summary 

  • Below you will find information covered in this module: 
    • Business law, often known as commercial law or mercantile law, refers to the collection of rules, whether by convention, agreement, or national or international law, that govern the interactions between parties in commercial concerns.
    • There are two different areas of business law: (1) the regulation of commercial entities by the laws of company, partnership, agency, and bankruptcy; and (2) the control of commercial transactions by the laws of contract and related subjects.
    • The legal system of the European Union (as opposed to the national laws of the member states). It is comprised of the EU's founding treaties (together with later amending treaties), Community law, and judgements of the European Court of Justice. 
    • Any provision of the treaties or of Community legislation that is immediately applicable or directly effective in a member state is incorporated into the law of that state and takes precedence over its national law in the case of a conflict.
    • The Judicial Committee of the Privy Council is the highest court of appeal for Commonwealth nations that have retained appeals to either Her Majesty's Council or the Judicial Committee. It is also the ultimate court of appeal for the High Court of Justice in Scotland on devolution-related matters. In 2009, the new Supreme Court assumed some of the Judicial Committee's responsibilities.
    • The Civil Division of the Court of Appeal considers civil law and family justice appeals from the High Court, tribunals, and some County Court matters.

  • Understanding Business Law - Lesson Summary 

  • Below you will find information covered in this module: 
    • Business law, often known as commercial law or mercantile law, refers to the collection of rules, whether by convention, agreement, or national or international law, that govern the interactions between parties in commercial concerns.
    • There are two different areas of business law: (1) the regulation of commercial entities by the laws of company, partnership, agency, and bankruptcy; and (2) the control of commercial transactions by the laws of contract and related subjects.
    • The legal system of the European Union (as opposed to the national laws of the member states). It is comprised of the EU's founding treaties (together with later amending treaties), Community law, and judgements of the European Court of Justice. 
    • Any provision of the treaties or of Community legislation that is immediately applicable or directly effective in a member state is incorporated into the law of that state and takes precedence over its national law in the case of a conflict.
    • The Judicial Committee of the Privy Council is the highest court of appeal for Commonwealth nations that have retained appeals to either Her Majesty's Council or the Judicial Committee. It is also the ultimate court of appeal for the High Court of Justice in Scotland on devolution-related matters. In 2009, the new Supreme Court assumed some of the Judicial Committee's responsibilities.
    • The Civil Division of the Court of Appeal considers civil law and family justice appeals from the High Court, tribunals, and some County Court matters.

  • Organisations and Property - Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Analyse the various regulations governing agency law.
    • Identify consumer protection laws and laws protecting consumers.
    • Arrange some thoughts concerning the law of torts.
    • Recognise the characteristics that distinguish business organisations.
    • Explain some of the fundamental concepts that underlie company law.
    • Summarise a concise explanation of the concepts of business property law and competition law.

  • Organisations and Property - Learning Outcomes

  • Below you will find key information covered in this module:
    • The agent owes the principal both contractual and fiduciary responsibilities. The agency agreement should include contractual tasks, and the agent is responsible for carrying them out with reasonable care and skill and in accordance with the principal's reasonable instructions. 
    • The agent's fiduciary obligations necessitate that they put the principal's interests ahead of their own and diligently carry out the agency's responsibilities.
    • The duration of an agency agreement might be fixed (for instance, 12 months) or unlimited. If the agreement continued beyond the end of the set term, it will be assumed that it became an indefinite arrangement.
    • When purchasing a product or service, consumer law protects consumers against concerns such as fraud and misrepresentation. The norms and restrictions of this directive must be followed by consumer markets.
    • The law of tort is a comprehensive corpus of rights, obligations, and remedies used by civil courts. It offers recourse to people who have suffered loss or damage due to the wrongdoing or negligence of others.
    • Anyone who has experienced suffering or loss as a result of another person's civil wrong may file a tort claim. There is the possibility for children to file lawsuits, including children born with impairments as a result of prenatal injury; spouses can also file lawsuits against one another.
    • Compliance entails ensuring that businesses of all sizes and their personnel adhere to current national and international rules. The Companies Act 2006 is the principal source of company law in the United Kingdom.

  • Organisations and Property - Learning Outcomes
